body:
This has absolutely nothing to do with code but I want to get the opinions of the core developers.

I am thinking of starting a newsletter to keep backers as well as other people curious about the Neovim development up to date without having to sift through the Issues/Pull requests.

@justinmk is doing a great job with the Wiki but something sitting in people's inbox about the development in the last week or two might be enticing.

My source of inspiration is [This Week in Rust](http://blog.octayn.net/categories.html#This-Week-in-Rust-ref). They have sections on:
- Changes on the `master` branch.
- Other changes.
- New contributors.
- A list of RFCs, Request for Comments.
- Community Updates.

Other possible sections:
- Highlighting those that have donated for transparency (@tarruda and I have talked about this).
- New bounties.

Some things that I'd like comments on:
- Is this something you'd like to see? Would it be beneficial to the community?
- How often would you like it? Weekly? Every other week (bi-monthly)? Monthly?
- Any other suggestions on what could be featured?
- Where should it live? If it should be separate from Neovim proper, I have no problem with that; that's how This Week in Rust is ran. Some guy just hosts it on his blog.

Also, I don't want it to interfere with the development in anyway so I won't ask for any of the main developers time for obvious reasons. My goal is purely for community engagement & transparency with the people that have supported Neovim in various ways.

Thanks everyone =]

comment_data.body: I think it could be a good idea, but I don't know if the rate of change merits that. The pace of reportable development tends to differ from month to month, so monthly might be ok. The way I usually prefer to get news from projects I follow is by subscribing to their RSS feeds with [newsbeuter](http://www.newsbeuter.org/). That way it doesn't clutter my mailbox either and I can "pull" news when I have the time instead of having to mark it as "read-later" or get annoyed that it's there while I have work to do. So maybe we could post these monthly oversights to the website and have each post reflected in an RSS feed?
:+1: on the monthly frequency and RSS feed ideas. That would be a perfect solution to handling it.

Currently, most work is spent on low-level refactoring. And there's still a lot of that kind of work to do. That is necessary, as a way for us to study/understand current code, and more importantly, to enable more people to more easily understand the code in future, so that new features/improvements can then be added with less effort.

That's a hell of a lot of hard work, but it doesn't produce many shiny news to show to users. Only @tarruda's advances in promised milestones, and some other few contributions here and there are of general interest.

That's why I  think monthly periodicity should be enough by now (even every two months). For advances of particular interest (like recent @tarruda changes on plugin/ui architecture) occurring in the middle of two regular issues, _special_ posts could be issued.

Apart from that, I think yours is a great initiative than can definitely help to spread the word and keep people's enthusiasm up.
Thanks!
@elmart I suspect you mean 'once every two months' by bi-monthly right? I think when jdavis uses it it means twice a month.
@jmlucjav You're right. With _even bimonthly_ I meant _even every two months_. I edited above post to avoid confusion. Thanks for clarifying, and sorry for that.

Yeah I am already sick and tired of visiting github page of the project to see if _what's been done so far_ section of Readme file was changed or not...

A newsletter would be definitely helpful guys. Thanks..

Thanks for the input, @rockneverdies55. I'm sure there are more of you out there. Maybe I could ask the Neovim followers on Twitter to see what they think as well?

Sorry about that. Apparently bimonthly has two different incohesive meanings, haha. I meant twice a month but I agree in that it might be too frequent.

I think every other month might be a bit too infrequent; that might just be me though. Personally I like once a month as @aktau suggested.

Also, I agree, @elmart, in that the idea of refactoring itself doesn't "produce many shiny news to show to users." However, the way it is refactored and how the code is changing could be pretty exciting to those that have to work with legacy code.

For "general interest" we have the Twitter account for that. I've been trying to keep it as general as possible without putting too much developer talk on it.

Regardless, I really appreciate the feedback.

I think this is a great idea. I've been watching all the activity on github
and a lot of it goes over my head so something that sits between the
everyday commit message and discussion, and the wiki would be really
interesting.

I'm sure someone with interest and understanding of the project could
easily have enough for once a month which would be little enough not to be
clogging inboxes or RSS clients.

I think it would also be a very accessible way of outsiders finding out
about the project as well as showing that the people involved are
interacting with the wider community, as well as the twitter, g+ etc, in a
more traditional open source way - email/rss.

You'd have the support of this humble observer, moral and practical if I
can help in any way.

As a possible part of such a "publication" I think it would be fascinating
to have a short interview or just some thoughts from some of the developers
and regulars themselves every now and then. Obviously nothing that they
would need to go out of their way for, but it would be great to show and
see you guys are real people doing a great job and giving your time.

Thanks.

(Just firing off some thoughts now) Also, you could include mention of some
of the easier level tasks, especially something like the translation tag, a
good newsletter has the ability to reach many people with many talents and
languages, a good set of solid translations is a real boon for an open
source project.

Cool, thanks for the thoughts @joshaw. I also think the short interview idea is a neat idea if any of the developers had time. And yeah, I totally agree in that a good newsletter has the potential to be a boon for OSS like you mentioned.

Also, where should this live? Would the [development-wiki](https://github.com/neovim/development-wiki) repo be an appropriate place? A new repo? Or should I do it through my own means with no Neovim affiliation?

I try to keep an Evernote note updated with the notable refactorings and new features [1]. May be helpful here.

It should be cleaned up, improved with links to relevant PRs/issues, better sorted and added to the README.

[1] https://www.evernote.com/shard/s102/sh/86b655b1-c7eb-4822-8423-99130ad1b877/5485150b94f0a23bb378cdac47ecf983
That's awesome, @philix. Thanks for that link!

I also asked just to see what the community thought and they seemed pretty supportive of it: https://twitter.com/Neovim/status/471385995808481280

Also, @justinmk, if you could comment on this item, I'd love for your input: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/771#issuecomment-44459728

Wow, that's a definitive response if ever I saw one.

Hosting-wise, is there reasons to not have it as a page on the neovim.org website? That way there are links to bountysource, the dev wiki etc. I think it should be possible to subscribe in some way, RSS or email, as @aktau said. I wonder if keeping it in the same place as the wiki will limit the possibilities of keeping up to date without getting all changes to the wiki for dev purposes.

Yup, it could definitely go on the homepage, I just wanted to get some opinions first.

I don't have permissions for the [neovim.github.io](https://github.com/neovim/neovim.github.io) repo and would have to do everything through pull requests.

@jdavis I'm neutral on the idea of interviews.

> Also, where should this live? Would the development-wiki repo be an appropriate place? A new repo? Or should I do it through my own means with no Neovim affiliation?

If you're running the newsletter, by all means it should be linked from neovim.org as a subpage.

I actually wish neovim.org and the dev-wiki were more integrated. Why are they separate repos? Don't they both use jekyll? The navigation should be consistent on both. @cweagans What are your thoughts?

@justinmk K. That's what I planned on, I created a [`newsletter`](https://github.com/jdavis/neovim.github.io/tree/newsletter) that I've been working on.

I think it'd be great to have a newsletter this week. Possibly we could make it the first Friday of every month so that this Friday would be the first one?

Also, I totally agree in that the sites should be merged (yup, they both run Jekyll)... I'm a bit limited on what I can do though as I only have access to the dev-wiki. And there was a strong push at the beginning of neovim.org's creation to keep the site as simple as possible; I didn't want to rock any boats.

I could merge the sites this week as well as write up the first newsletter for this Friday. That'd be fun =]

I agree that the site should be simple. I think in the beginning there were some webdevs proclaiming the joys of drupal etc, but at this point we don't have anyone advocating that kind of stuff. 

@tarruda @jbranchaud @cweagans dev-wiki is minimal, and neovim.org is a single page. Any comment on merging dev-wiki with neovim.org, with the understanding that neovim.org will continue to be extremely simple (for maintainability as well as user-facing content)?

title: Weekly or bi-monthly newsletter
